title: Google parent company Alphabet announces massive $5bn share buyback
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Oct 22, 2015, 23:40 BST - UK Markets closed Google parent company Alphabet announces massive $5bn share buyback By James Titcomb | Telegraph – 31 minutes ago +15.50 
The repurchase programme is the first time that the company has returned cash to shareholders 
Alphabet (Xetra: ABEA.DE - news ) , the new parent company of Google , has announced it will spend over $5bn (£3.3bn) on an enormous share buyback, the first time the company has returned some of its swelling cash pile to shareholders. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) leapt in after-hours trading, climbing by around 10pc after the company also unveiled better-than-expected profits. 
Google recently announced a radical overhaul of its corporate structure , saying it would split its massively profitable core business from its research divisions such as its robotics arm and medical research unit, all under the Alphabet parent company. 
In the last set of quarterly results before it reports under the new structure, the company revealed a 13pc increase in third-quarter revenue to $18.7bn and a profit of $4bn, up from $2.7bn a year ago. 
As cash holdings grew to $72.3bn, Alphabet said it would pay just under $5.1bn on a stock buyback. 
In an apparent sign that Google does not plan on forgetting its roots under the new corporate structure, the exact sum of the buyback is $5,099,019,513.59, the square root of 26 the number of letters in the alphabet - multiplied by one billion. Google's chief financial officer Ruth Porat said the sum had been reached as a result of some "fun math". 
The vast majority of the company’s revenues come from advertising on Google’s websites, which investors have fretted over as internet users increasingly go online on their smartphones, where adverts can be less lucrative. 
For the first time, searches on smartphones overtook those on desktops during the last quarter. But despite Google’s “cost per click” the average amount advertisers pay every time someone clicks on an advert falling by 11pc, Alphabet said Google had seen “substantial growth” in mobile search revenue. 
Shares in the company rose by around 10pc immediately following the results, climbing to an all-time high and valuing Alphabet at more than $500bn.
